options.text: Theological differences between Islam and Judaism

multiple-choice.question: Who issued the Balfour Declaration in 1917, promising a national home for the Jewish people in Palestine?
What was the population of Palestine in 1878, according to Ottoman records?
What was the name of the Jewish journalist who advocated for Jewish nationalism and the creation of a Jewish state?
What was the result of the 1948 Arab-Israeli War?

options.label: A
options.text: Israel was defeated, and Palestine became an independent state.

options.label: B
options.text: Israel won, and Palestine was divided into separate states.

options.label: C
options.text: The war ended in a stalemate, and the United Nations intervened.

options.label: D
options.text: Israel occupied a third more land than they would have had under the UN proposal.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the resolution passed by the United Nations in 1967, outlining a framework for achieving peace in the Middle East?
Who led the Palestinian Liberation Organization (PLO) and was a key figure in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict?
What was the name of the first intifada, which began in the late 1980s?
What was the result of the Clinton talks between Israel and Palestine?

options.label: A
options.text: A peace agreement was reached, and a Palestinian state was established.

options.label: B
options.text: The talks failed, and the conflict continued.

options.label: C
options.text: Israel agreed to withdraw from the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

options.label: D
options.text: Palestine agreed to recognize Israel's right to exist.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the barrier built by Israel around the West Bank, which has been a source of controversy and tension?

title: What causes migraines? - Marianne Schwarz

multiple-choice.question: What are some common warning signs of a migraine in the days and hours leading up to it?

options.label: A
options.text: Fatigue, mood changes, and increased appetite

options.label: B
options.text: Fatigue, mood changes, bursts of yawning, and sleep disruption

multiple-choice.question: Which part of the brain is more active than usual in the days before a migraine and controls the systems behind the warning signs?
What is the migraine aura, and what can it cause?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of headache that causes visual changes

options.label: B
options.text: A warning sign that causes nausea and vomiting

options.label: C
options.text: A change in charge across cell membranes that leads to transient visual changes, tingling, or trouble speaking

options.label: D
options.text: A type of medication that treats migraines

multiple-choice.question: Which nerve plays a key role in transmitting pain signals during the headache phase of a migraine?
What percentage of women and men are affected by migraines in their lifetimes?
What is thought to have a role in the difference in migraine frequency between men and women?
What is the relationship between migraines and other illnesses such as depression and sleep disorders?

options.label: C
options.text: The relationship is likely complex and may reflect the effect of migraine on these diseases or vice versa, or their shared genetic basis

options.label: D
options.text: There is no relationship between migraines and these illnesses

multiple-choice.question: What role do genetics play in migraines?

options.label: A
options.text: There is a single gene that causes migraines

options.label: B
options.text: Genetics play no role in migraines

options.label: C
options.text: Certain genes control how easily our brains' neurons are excited by environmental stimuli and how readily they transmit painful signals

options.label: D
options.text: Genetics only play a role in women with migraines

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the pain pathway during a migraine?
Why is migraine considered a complex disorder?

options.label: C
options.text: Because it affects multiple parts of the brain and has a complex relationship with other illnesses

title: Should you donate your DNA to help cure diseases? - Greg Foot

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the main reasons why developing a new drug takes a long time?

options.label: A
options.text: Lack of funding from pharmaceutical companies

options.label: B
options.text: Limited understanding of the cause of a condition

options.label: C
options.text: Insufficient number of researchers working on the project

multiple-choice.question: What is medical crowdsourcing, and how can individuals contribute to it?

options.label: A
options.text: Donating money to fund research on new drugs

options.label: B
options.text: Donating genetic data and health history to help discover new therapeutic targets

options.label: C
options.text: Participating in clinical trials for new drugs

multiple-choice.question: How were many of the first medicines discovered?

options.label: B
options.text: By chance, with natural philosophers later identifying the active chemicals

options.label: C
options.text: Through the use of advanced technology and AI

options.label: D
options.text: By studying the effects of different substances on animals

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of proteins in disease, and how do drugs treat disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Proteins are the cause of disease, and drugs eliminate them

options.label: B
options.text: Proteins are the result of disease, and drugs reduce their production

options.label: C
options.text: Proteins malfunction, causing disease, and drugs target those malfunctioning proteins

options.label: D
options.text: Proteins are unaffected by disease, and drugs work on other molecules

multiple-choice.question: Why is identifying therapeutic targets a slow process?

options.label: A
options.text: Due to the complexity of DNA and the large number of proteins involved in each disease

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the limited number of researchers working on the project

options.label: C
options.text: As a result of the high cost of conducting clinical trials

options.label: D
options.text: Due to the lack of funding from pharmaceutical companies

multiple-choice.question: What do researchers hope to achieve by comparing the genomes of people with similar conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: Identify new genetic mutations that cause disease

options.label: B
options.text: Develop new, more effective treatments for existing diseases

options.label: C
options.text: Discover new therapeutic targets for currently untreatable diseases

options.label: D
options.text: Understand the role of environmental factors in disease development

multiple-choice.question: What are the three options researchers have when they identify a new therapeutic target?

options.label: A
options.text: Start a clinical trial, develop a new drug, or abandon the target

options.label: B
options.text: Investigate whether the target has been previously linked to a different disease, design a new drug, or start a clinical trial

options.label: C
options.text: Use AI machine learning to design a new drug, conduct a clinical trial, or analyze the target's structure

options.label: D
options.text: Determine whether the target is a protein, a gene, or a molecular machine

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated proportion of proteins in the human body that may have a drug that can bind to them?
Who are the two groups that may have access to an individual's genetic data, and what might they do with it?

options.label: A
options.text: Pharmaceutical companies and private consumer genetic testing companies, who may use it for research and profit

options.label: B
options.text: Healthcare providers and researchers, who may use it to provide personalized care and develop new treatments

options.label: C
options.text: Government agencies and insurance companies, who may use it to make policy decisions and determine premiums

options.label: D
options.text: Academic institutions and non-profit organizations, who may use it for educational purposes and fundraising

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential benefit of genomics in drug development, and what should individuals do before contributing their data?

options.label: A
options.text: Genomics can speed up the development of new drugs, and individuals should research the organizations asking for their data

options.label: B
options.text: Genomics can reduce the cost of new drugs, and individuals should consult with their healthcare providers before contributing data

options.label: C
options.text: Genomics can improve the efficacy of existing treatments, and individuals should carefully review the terms and conditions of data sharing

options.label: D
options.text: Genomics can increase the understanding of disease mechanisms, and individuals should ensure that their data is anonymized and secure

title: The electrical blueprints that orchestrate life - Michael Levin

multiple-choice.question: According to Michael Levin, what is the traditional model of understanding how cells develop and grow in an organism?

options.label: A
options.text: Cells communicate with each other through electrical signals to determine their development.

options.label: B
options.text: Cells are controlled by a hardwired set of movements to determine their development.

options.label: C
options.text: Cells communicate with each other through biochemical signals to determine their development.

options.label: D
options.text: Cells develop and grow randomly without any specific signals or controls.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the ability of cells to communicate with each other using electrical signals?
According to Michael Levin, what is the key to understanding how organisms develop and grow?

options.label: A
options.text: Understanding the biochemical signals between cells

options.label: B
options.text: Understanding the electrical signals between cells

options.label: C
options.text: Understanding the genetic code of the organism

options.label: D
options.text: Understanding the environmental factors that affect the organism

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the creature that Michael Levin and his team have used to study regeneration and bioelectricity?
What is the term used to describe the ability of an organism to regrow or repair damaged or missing body parts?
According to Michael Levin, what is the potential application of understanding bioelectricity in medicine?

options.label: B
options.text: Developing new treatments for degenerative diseases

options.label: C
options.text: Developing new treatments for birth defects

multiple-choice.question: What is a xenobot, according to Michael Levin?

options.label: D
options.text: A novel life-form created from genetically unaltered cells

multiple-choice.question: According to Michael Levin, what is the key to creating a xenobot?

options.label: B
options.text: Manipulating the electrical signals between cells

options.label: C
options.text: Using biochemical signals to control the cells

options.label: D
options.text: Creating a new type of cell

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential application of xenobots in medicine, according to Michael Levin?

options.label: A
options.text: Delivering pro-regenerative compounds to damaged tissues

multiple-choice.question: According to Michael Levin, what is the importance of understanding bioelectricity in the field of biology?

options.label: A
options.text: It can help us understand how cells communicate with each other

options.label: B
options.text: It can help us understand how organisms develop and grow

options.label: C
options.text: It can help us develop new treatments for diseases

title: Meet the bluefin tuna, the toughest fish in the sea - Grantly Galland and Raiana McKinney

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the way Atlantic bluefin tuna regulate their body temperature?

options.label: A
options.text: They use external sources of heat to warm their bodies.

options.label: B
options.text: They have a specialized network of blood vessels that trap heat.

options.label: C
options.text: They lose heat through their gills like most other fish.

options.label: D
options.text: They only swim in warm waters to maintain their body temperature.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary advantage of being warm-blooded for Atlantic bluefin tuna?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows them to blend in with their surroundings.

options.label: B
options.text: It enables them to change color to communicate with other tuna.

options.label: C
options.text: It gives them sharper vision, better information processing, and faster swimming speeds.

options.label: D
options.text: It makes them more vulnerable to predators.

multiple-choice.question: What is the maximum speed that Atlantic bluefin tuna can reach?
Why do Atlantic bluefin tuna need to constantly remain on the move?

options.label: D
options.text: To absorb oxygen from the water

multiple-choice.question: How do Atlantic bluefin tuna typically catch their prey?

options.label: A
options.text: By sucking it into their mouths

options.label: B
options.text: By chasing it down with their mouths open

options.label: C
options.text: By using camouflage to sneak up on it

options.label: D
options.text: By using their powerful fins to stun it

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the migration patterns of Atlantic bluefin tuna?

options.label: B
options.text: They migrate alone, rather than in groups.

options.label: C
options.text: They return to their sea of origin to reproduce.

options.label: D
options.text: They only migrate at certain times of the year.

multiple-choice.question: How long can Atlantic bluefin tuna live?
What is the main reason why Atlantic bluefin tuna are vulnerable to overfishing?

options.label: A
options.text: Their small size makes them easy to catch.

options.label: B
options.text: Their slow swimming speed makes them easy to catch.

options.label: C
options.text: Their huge size makes them valuable to fishermen.

options.label: D
options.text: Their limited range makes them easy to target.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the main products that drives the demand for Atlantic bluefin tuna?
What is necessary for Atlantic bluefin tuna populations to begin to recover?

options.label: C
options.text: Better enforcement of existing quotas and conservation efforts

options.label: D
options.text: The introduction of new tuna species to the Atlantic Ocean

title: How to have constructive conversations - Julia Dhar

multiple-choice.question: What motivated the speaker's dad to travel from Australia to the US in November 2016?

options.label: B
options.text: To talk to Americans about the election

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker's dad want to achieve through his conversations with Americans?

options.label: A
options.text: To convince them of his point of view

options.label: B
options.text: To listen, be heard, and understand

options.label: C
options.text: To gather data for a research project

multiple-choice.question: What is "belief perseverance" in social psychology?

options.label: A
options.text: The tendency to change one's beliefs easily

options.label: B
options.text: The tendency to hold onto one's beliefs despite new information

options.label: C
options.text: The tendency to ignore opposing viewpoints

options.label: D
options.text: The tendency to seek out diverse perspectives

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of a "curiosity conversation"?

options.label: B
options.text: To understand the other person's perspective

options.label: C
options.text: To convince the other person of one's point of view

multiple-choice.question: What is the "curiosity conversation" technique popularized by Brian Grazer?

options.label: A
options.text: Asking a series of confrontational questions

options.label: B
options.text: Making a statement and asking a follow-up question

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of approaching conversations as a "climbing wall"?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows for a quick resolution

options.label: C
options.text: It fosters progress and understanding over time

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of "development" in constructive conversations?

options.label: A
options.text: To criticize the other person's ideas

options.label: C
options.text: To adapt and improve one's ideas through challenge and criticism

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of having a clear purpose in conversations?

options.label: C
options.text: It allows for a clear understanding of the conversation's goals

multiple-choice.question: What is "disagreement time travel"?

options.label: B
options.text: A method for convincing others of one's point of view

options.label: C
options.text: A way of exploring a future possibility to find common ground

options.label: D
options.text: A strategy for winning an argument

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to bringing together individuals with different perspectives, according to the deputy prime minister of New Zealand?

options.label: C
options.text: Reminding them of their shared purpose

title: How long should your naps be? - Sara C. Mednick

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate duration of a sleep cycle in both nighttime sleep and naps?
What is the primary characteristic of Stage 2 sleep?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased brain activity and vivid dreams

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased body temperature, relaxed muscles, and regular breathing

options.label: C
options.text: Rapid bursts of neural activity called sleep spindles

multiple-choice.question: Which stage of sleep is associated with long-term potentiation, a process that strengthens synapses between neurons?
What is the typical duration of REM sleep in a nap?

How does the time of day affect the need for deep Stage 3 sleep?

options.label: B
options.text: It remains constant throughout the day

options.label: C
options.text: It progressively increases throughout the day

options.label: D
options.text: It is unaffected by the time of day

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary difference between morning, midday, and evening naps in terms of sleep stages?

options.label: A
options.text: Morning naps have more deep sleep, while evening naps have more REM sleep

options.label: B
options.text: Morning naps have more REM sleep, while evening naps have more deep sleep

options.label: C
options.text: Midday naps have equal parts of REM and deep sleep

multiple-choice.question: According to researchers, why might non-nappers not experience cognitive benefits from napping?

options.label: A
options.text: They are unable to fall asleep quickly

options.label: B
options.text: They experience more deep sleep while napping, leading to grogginess

options.label: C
options.text: They are not able to stay in a lighter sleep stage

options.label: D
options.text: They have a different sleep cycle duration

multiple-choice.question: What is the typical duration of a nap that includes both Stage 2 and Stage 3 sleep?
What is the primary characteristic of Stage 3 sleep?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased brain activity and vivid dreams

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased body temperature and relaxed muscles

options.label: C
options.text: Slow waves and coordinated neural activity

options.label: D
options.text: Rapid bursts of neural activity called sleep spindles

title: Can you solve Dongle's Difficult Dilemma? - Dennis E. Shasha

multiple-choice.question: According to legend, what did the three galactic terraformers leave behind when they finished shaping the planet?

options.label: C
options.text: A set of rules for auctions

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of collecting three golden or silver hexagons?

options.label: A
options.text: To defeat the evil wizard Gordon

multiple-choice.question: Who is Dongle, and what is his motivation?

options.label: A
options.text: An evil wizard who wants to enslave the world

options.label: C
options.text: A hero who wants to save the world

options.label: D
options.text: A bystander who stumbled upon the hexagons

multiple-choice.question: What is Gordon's advantage in the bidding war?

options.label: A
options.text: He has more gems than the protagonist

options.label: B
options.text: He has a magical mirror that lets him see the protagonist's bids

options.label: C
options.text: He has already collected two golden hexagons

options.label: D
options.text: He has a special auction strategy

multiple-choice.question: What is the protagonist's goal in the bidding war?

options.label: A
options.text: To win the golden hexagons outright

options.label: B
options.text: To save as much as possible for the silver hexagons

options.label: C
options.text: To force Gordon to spend enough on the golds to guarantee a win on the silvers

options.label: D
options.text: To bid randomly and hope for the best

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to winning the silver auctions?

options.label: B
options.text: Having a one-gem advantage and dividing gems into three groups

multiple-choice.question: How can the protagonist force Gordon's hand in the gold auctions?

options.label: A
options.text: By bidding everything on the second gold auction

options.label: B
options.text: By bidding at most 24 on the second gold auction

options.label: D
options.text: By using a special auction strategy

multiple-choice.question: What happens if Gordon wins the second gold auction against the protagonist's bid of 24?

options.label: A
options.text: The protagonist loses the bidding war

options.label: B
options.text: The protagonist can still win the silver auctions

options.label: C
options.text: The protagonist must bid everything on the third gold auction

options.label: D
options.text: The protagonist must concede the bidding war

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome of the bidding war?

options.label: B
options.text: The protagonist wins the golden hexagons

options.label: C
options.text: The protagonist wins the silver hexagons

options.label: D
options.text: The bidding war ends in a tie

multiple-choice.question: What does the protagonist gain by winning the silver hexagons?

options.label: B
options.text: The power to recreate the world

options.label: D
options.text: A set of rules for auctions

title: The world’s most painful insect sting - Justin Schmidt

multiple-choice.question: Which scientist created the sting pain index that ranks the pain of around 100 kinds of insect stings?
What is the name of the pain-causing peptide found in the venom of Western honeybees?
Why do worker honeybees usually die after stinging a victim?

options.label: A
options.text: Because their venom is too potent for their own bodies

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are allergic to their own venom

options.label: C
options.text: Because their barbed stingers get stuck in the victim's skin

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are too exhausted from flying

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of the alarm pheromone released by worker honeybees after they sting a victim?

options.label: A
options.text: To attract more bees to the area for foraging

options.label: B
options.text: To activate a mass attack on the victim

options.label: C
options.text: To communicate with other bees about food sources

options.label: D
options.text: To mark the victim as a threat

multiple-choice.question: How long does the pain from a tarantula hawk wasp sting typically last in humans?

Why do bullet ants have such an excruciating defense mechanism?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are apex predators in their ecosystem

options.label: B
options.text: Because they forage in rainforest canopies loaded with predators

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are competing with other ants for resources

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are trying to attract mates

multiple-choice.question: Which insect has the most painful sting according to the sting pain index?
What is the primary purpose of the tarantula hawk wasp's sting?

options.label: B
options.text: To paralyze the tarantula and lay an egg on it

multiple-choice.question: Why do insect stings help enable the evolution of complex colonies?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they provide a defense mechanism against predators

options.label: C
options.text: Because they help colonies to forage for food more efficiently

options.label: D
options.text: Because they allow colonies to migrate to new areas

title: How compassion could save your strained relationships - Betty Hart

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is cancel culture in the bigger society?

options.label: A
options.text: When a person in prominence does something that the people agree with

options.label: B
options.text: When a person in prominence says or does something that the people disagree with, and the decision is made to make them persona non grata

options.label: C
options.text: When people choose to suffer alongside someone

options.label: D
options.text: When people decide to plant seeds of change

multiple-choice.question: What is the first premise that exists when we indulge in cancel culture, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: We have to believe that the other person has the ability to change

options.label: B
options.text: We have to believe that we're right, with no possibility of being wrong

options.label: C
options.text: We have to believe that the other person is always wrong

options.label: D
options.text: We have to believe that we're always wrong

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the definition of compassion?
What is the speaker suggesting as an alternative to cancel culture?
According to the speaker, what happens when we choose to cancel someone?

options.label: A
options.text: We get to hear their point of view

options.label: B
options.text: We get to share our point of view

options.label: C
options.text: We are no longer in proximity to them

multiple-choice.question: The speaker mentions the late justices Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Antonin Scalia as an example of:

options.label: B
options.text: People who suffered alongside each other despite their differences

options.label: C
options.text: People who changed each other's minds

options.label: D
options.text: People who never spoke to each other

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the result of choosing to suffer alongside someone?

options.label: A
options.text: We value one particular aspect of the person

options.label: B
options.text: We value the totality of the person

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the speaker's decision to reach out to their father after 10 years of not talking?

options.label: B
options.text: They continued to disagree on everything

options.label: C
options.text: They reconnected and their love continued

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the benefit of choosing curiosity and empathy?

options.label: B
options.text: We become more entrenched in our beliefs

options.label: C
options.text: We might discover something new and understand the context for why someone believes what they believe

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker encouraging society to become?

options.label: A
options.text: A society of people who choose canceling over compassion

options.label: B
options.text: A society of people who choose compassion over canceling

options.label: C
options.text: A society of people who choose empathy over curiosity

options.label: D
options.text: A society of people who choose suffering over love
